required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparative Effectiveness and Safety of Inhaled Corticosteroids and Antimicrobial Compounds for Non-CF Bronchiectasis
clinical_study.official_title: Comparative Effectiveness and Safety of Inhaled Corticosteroids and Antimicrobial Compounds for Non-CF Bronchiectasis

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to provide patients and their physicians with greater understanding of the risks and benefits of commonly used therapies for treatment of non-CF bronchiectasis

detailed_description.textblock: Non-CF bronchiectasis is a chronic inflammatory lung disease that is closely linked to pulmonary NTM disease. Both are rare but rising in incidence and disproportionately affect the elderly and women. Therapy of non-CF bronchiectasis aims to reduce inflammation via either ICS-induced immunosuppression or antibiotic-associated immunomodulation and/or suppression of pathogenic organisms. Both strategies, pursued long-term alone or some cases concomitantly, have inherent risks, and the relative risks and benefits of these differential approaches are poorly studied to date. Ultimately, our study will provide patients and their physicians with greater understanding of the risks and benefits of these therapeutic choices.

primary_outcome.description: Incidence of treated pulmonary nontuberculous mycobacterium (NTM) disease
Among a national cohort of non-CF bronchiectasis patients, we will compare the effectiveness of corticosteroid and macrolide therapy with regards to prevention of hospitalized respiratory infection.

arm_group.description: Complete national 2006-2014 Medicare data from Part A, B and D will be obtained from CMS. We will use bronchiectasis ICD-9 codes 494.0 and 494.1 to identify patients with bronchiectasis within Medicare. From this identified bronchiectasis cohort, we will exclude patients with cystic fibrosis (ICD-9 codes 277.00-277.09), HIV infection (042), and a history of organ transplant (V42.0, V42.1, V42.6, V42.7, V42.8).

intervention.description: We will evaluate and compare the clinical effectiveness and safety of long-term inhaled corticosteroid and macrolide antimicrobial therapies
We will evaluate and compare the clinical effectiveness and safety of long-term inhaled corticosteroid and macrolide antimicrobial therapies

study_pop.textblock: Patients within Medicare with a diagnosis of bronchiectasis

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Within Medicare data, indicated diagnosis of Bronchiectasis by a Pulmonologist (ICD-9 code 494.0 and/or 494.1)
Exclusion Criteria:
- cystic fibrosis diagnosis, HIV infection, history of organ transplant

reference.citation: Deyo RA, Cherkin DC, Ciol MA. Adapting a clinical comorbidity index for use with ICD-9-CM administrative databases. J Clin Epidemiol. 1992 Jun;45(6):613-9.
Charlson ME, Pompei P, Ales KL, MacKenzie CR. A new method of classifying prognostic comorbidity in longitudinal studies: development and validation. J Chronic Dis. 1987;40(5):373-83.

results_reference.citation: Henkle E, Curtis JR, Chen L, Chan B, Aksamit TR, Daley CL, Griffith DE, Winthrop KL. Comparative risks of chronic inhaled corticosteroids and macrolides for bronchiectasis. Eur Respir J. 2019 Jul 18;54(1). pii: 1801896. doi: 10.1183/13993003.01896-2018. Print 2019 Jul.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Associate Professor, Divisions of Infectious Diseases, and Public Health and Preventive Medicine

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Complete national 2006-2014 Medicare data from Part A, B and D (but not C) were obtained from Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services for patients with ICD-9-CM code 494.0 or 494.1 (bronchiectasis without or with acute exacerbation).
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: From the identified bronchiectasis cohort, we excluded patients with cystic fibrosis, HIV infection, or a history of organ transplant. Such patients are fundamentally different than non-CF bronchiectasis patients who lack these factors with regard to their risk for infection, hospitalization, and many of the outcomes under study in this proposal.

group.title: Inhaled Corticosteroids (ICS)
group.description: New use was defined as the first prescription for a minimum 28 day (“chronic”) supply of ICS after a clean period of 12 months with no chronic use of either exposure of interest. ICS included ICS alone or in combination with long-acting beta agonists.

group.title: Macrolide Monotherapy
group.description: New use was defined as the first prescription for a minimum 28 day (“chronic”) supply of macrolide monotherapy after a clean period of 12 months with no chronic use of either exposure of interest. Macrolide monotherapy was defined as oral azithromycin or erythromycin and no other chronic prescription within 30 days that could be associated with NTM therapy (ethambutol, a rifamycin, or a fluoroquinolone). Patients who did not start on macrolide monotherapy were excluded.

group.title: Inhaled Corticosteroids (ICS)
group.description: New use was defined as the first prescription for a minimum 28 day (“chronic”) supply of ICS after a clean period of 12 months with no chronic use of either exposure of interest. ICS included ICS alone or in combination with long-acting beta agonists.

group.title: Macrolide Monotherapy
group.description: New use was defined as the first prescription for a minimum 28 day (“chronic”) supply of macrolide monotherapy after a clean period of 12 months with no chronic use of either exposure of interest. Macrolide monotherapy was defined as oral azithromycin or erythromycin and no other chronic prescription within 30 days that could be associated with NTM therapy (ethambutol, a rifamycin, or a fluoroquinolone). Patients who did not start on macrolide monotherapy were excluded.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

measure.title: Physician encounters in the 12 month prior to Baseline
Pulmonologist encounters in the prior 12 months before baseline
Inpatient admissions in the 12 months prior to baseline
Hospitalized respiratory infections in the 12 months prior to baseline
Number of acute respiratory infections in the 12 months prior to baseline
Adapted Charlson comorbidity index (prior 12 months)
measure.description: Charlson comorbidity index, higher score is worse.

outcome.title: Nontuberculous Mycobacterial (NTM) Disease
outcome.description: Incidence of treated pulmonary nontuberculous mycobacterium (NTM) disease
outcome.population: Analysis population excluded all patients with a history of NTM treatment or diagnosis prior to exposure start.

group.title: Inhaled Corticosteroids (ICS)
group.description: New use was defined as the first prescription for a minimum 28 day (“chronic”) supply of ICS after a clean period of 12 months with no chronic use of either exposure of interest. ICS included ICS alone or in combination with long-acting beta agonists.

group.title: Macrolide Monotherapy
group.description: New use was defined as the first prescription for a minimum 28 day (“chronic”) supply of macrolide monotherapy after a clean period of 12 months with no chronic use of either exposure of interest. Macrolide monotherapy was defined as oral azithromycin or erythromycin and no other chronic prescription within 30 days that could be associated with NTM therapy (ethambutol, a rifamycin, or a fluoroquinolone). Patients who did not start on macrolide monotherapy were excluded.

measure.title: Nontuberculous Mycobacterial (NTM) Disease
measure.description: Incidence of treated pulmonary nontuberculous mycobacterium (NTM) disease
measure.population: Analysis population excluded all patients with a history of NTM treatment or diagnosis prior to exposure start.

analysis.groups_desc: Due to the small sample size in the macrolide monotherapy group, for this outcome, the results are considered exploratory/descriptive only.
analysis.method_desc: Adjusted for propensity score decile, oral corticosteroid use.

outcome.title: Hospitalized Respiratory Infection
outcome.description: Among a national cohort of non-CF bronchiectasis patients, we will compare the effectiveness of corticosteroid and macrolide therapy with regards to prevention of hospitalized respiratory infection.

group.title: Non-CF Bronchiectasis Patients on ICS Monotherapy
group.description: New use was defined as the first prescription for a minimum 28 day (“chronic”) supply of ICS after a clean period of 12 months with no chronic use of either exposure of interest. ICS included ICS alone or in combination with long-acting beta agonists.

group.title: Non-CF Bronchiectasis Patients on Macrolide Monotherapy
group.description: New use was defined as the first prescription for a minimum 28 day (“chronic”) supply of macrolide monotherapy after a clean period of 12 months with no chronic use of either exposure of interest. Macrolide monotherapy was defined as oral azithromycin or erythromycin and no other chronic prescription within 30 days that could be associated with NTM therapy (ethambutol, a rifamycin, or a fluoroquinolone). Patients who did not start on macrolide monotherapy were excluded.

measure.title: Hospitalized Respiratory Infection
measure.description: Among a national cohort of non-CF bronchiectasis patients, we will compare the effectiveness of corticosteroid and macrolide therapy with regards to prevention of hospitalized respiratory infection.

analysis.method_desc: Adjusted for propensity score decile, oral corticosteroid use, and NTM history.

group.title: Non-CF Bronchiectasis Patients on ICS Monotherapy
group.description: New use was defined as the first prescription for a minimum 28 day (“chronic”) supply of ICS after a clean period of 12 months with no chronic use of either exposure of interest. ICS included ICS alone or in combination with long-acting beta agonists.

group.title: Non-CF Bronchiectasis Patients on Macrolide Monotherapy
group.description: New use was defined as the first prescription for a minimum 28 day (“chronic”) supply of macrolide monotherapy after a clean period of 12 months with no chronic use of either exposure of interest. Macrolide monotherapy was defined as oral azithromycin or erythromycin and no other chronic prescription within 30 days that could be associated with NTM therapy (ethambutol, a rifamycin, or a fluoroquinolone). Patients who did not start on macrolide monotherapy were excluded.

analysis.method_desc: Adjusted for propensity score decile, oral corticosteroid use, and NTM history.

group.title: Non-CF Bronchiectasis Patients on ICS Monotherapy
group.description: Patients prescribed a 28 day or more supply of ICS, with an absence of ICS prescriptions for at least the 12 months prior to identified prescription. ICS include beclomethasone, budesonide, flunisolide, fluticasone, mometasone, triamcinolone, ipratropium/albuterol, budesonide/formoterol, or fluticasone/salmeterol. Exclude baseline 28+ day macrolide, missing geographic or socioeconomic data.

group.title: Non-CF Bronchiectasis Patients on Macrolide Monotherapy
group.description: Patients prescribed a 28 day or more supply of a macrolide, with an absence of macrolide prescriptions for at least the 12 months prior to identified prescription. Macrolides include oral azithromycin, clarithromycin, and erythromycin. Exclude baseline 28+ day ICS, missing geographic or socioeconomic data

analysis.method_desc: Adjusted for propensity score decile, oral corticosteroid use, and NTM history

reported_events.time_frame: This is a retrospective observational study. Only medical history data was collected.
reported_events.desc: All-Cause Mortality, Serious, and Other Adverse Events were not monitored. We report Safety Outcomes in the Outcomes section.

group.title: Non-CF Bronchiectasis Patients on ICS Monotherapy
group.description: Patients prescribed a 28 day or more supply of ICS, with an absence of ICS prescriptions for at least the 12 months prior to identified prescription. ICS include beclomethasone, budesonide, flunisolide, fluticasone, mometasone, triamcinolone, ipratropium/albuterol, budesonide/formoterol, or fluticasone/salmeterol. Exclude baseline 28+ day macrolide, missing geographic or socioeconomic data.

group.title: Non-CF Bronchiectasis Patients on Macrolide Monotherapy
group.description: Patients prescribed a 28 day or more supply of a macrolide, with an absence of macrolide prescriptions for at least the 12 months prior to identified prescription. Macrolides include oral azithromycin, clarithromycin, and erythromycin. Exclude baseline 28+ day ICS, missing geographic or socioeconomic data

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Claims-based data limits our ability to confirm bronchiectasis diagnoses and include disease symptoms/severity in our models. Results may not be applicable to <65 year old bronchiectasis patients who have a lower underlying risk of pneumonia.
